+
+class Client(object):
+    """A client attempting to fetch a set of recipes."""
+    def __init__(self, request):
+        self.request = request
+
+    @property
+    def locale(self):
+        pass
+
+    @property
+    def country(self):
+        pass
+
+    @property
+    def request_time(self):
+        return self.request.received_at
+
+
+class Bundle(object):
+    """A bundle of recipes to be sent to the client."""
+    def __init__(self, recipes=None):
+        self.recipes = recipes or []
+
+    @property

+        return [recipe.id for recipe in self.recipes]

+    @property

body_text: Nope, because __hash__ return values are ints and truncated to 4 or 8 bytes. SHA-1 returns a 20 byte string and we're going to shove the hash in a URL anyway, so converting it to an int and back to a hex string seems silly.
body: Nope, because [`__hash__` return values are ints and truncated to 4 or 8 bytes](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#object.__hash__). SHA-1 returns a 20 byte string and we're going to shove the hash in a URL anyway, so converting it to an int and back to a hex string seems silly.
